case_name: State of Orissa v. work-charged personnel of Hirakud Dam project

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 1492 of 1966 was filed by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 1492 of 1966. Appeal by special leave from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal is from the judgment and order dated April 5, 1968 of the Orissa High Court in O.J.C. No. 58 of 1965.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order date April 5, 1968 of the Orissa High Court in O.J.C. No. 58 of 1965.

facts.text: Decision was taken to construct three dams across the Mahanadi river: at Hirakud, Tikerpara and Naraj.

anchor.surface_text: A decision was taken to construct three dams right across the Mahanadi river, one at Hirakud, the second at Tikerpara and the third at Naraj as a multipurpose measure for preventing flood ravage

facts.text: Construction of Hirakud Dam was entrusted by the State of Orissa to the Central Waterways, Irrigation and Navigation Commission as their agent.

anchor.surface_text: The construction of Hirakud Dam was entrusted by the State of Orissa to the Central Waterways, Irrigation and Navigation Commission as their agent.

facts.text: C.W.I.N. Commission employed a large number of persons in the work-charged establishment governed by the Central Public Works Department Code.

anchor.surface_text: For the purpose of the construction of Hirakud Dam, the C.W.I.N. Commission employed a large number of persons in the work- charged establishment on scales of remuneration at the rate paid by the Central Public Works Department

facts.text: After completion of the first stage of the Hirakud Dam project, the State of Orissa took over the project from C.W.I.N. Commission with effect from April 1, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: After completion of the first stage of the Hirakud Dam project, the State of Orissa decided to take over the said project from their agent the C.W.I.N. Commission with effect from April 1, 1960.

facts.text: State decided to proceed with construction of second stage through its own Public Works Department.

anchor.surface_text: The State further decided to proceed with the construction of second stage of the project through its own Public Works Department.

facts.text: Option was given by the State to employees in work-charged establishment to continue under State on same pay, allowances and conditions under the Code.

anchor.surface_text: An option was given by the State to the employees in the work charged establishment to decide whether they Would continue to work under the State on the same pay and allowances and subject to other conditions of service provided in the Code

facts.text: Employees agreed to work under the State of Orissa and were allowed to continue.

anchor.surface_text: The employees agreed to work under the State of Orissa and accordingly the employees. were allowed to continue under the State Government.

facts.text: Hirakud Control Board recommended to State Government to terminate services of work-charged personnel of Hirakud Dam by giving one month's notice with effect from March 31, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: The Hirakud Control Board recommended to the State Government to terminate the services of the work-charged personnel of the Hirakund Dam by giving one months notice with effect from March 31, 1963.

facts.text: State Government terminated services of the personnel with effect from March 31, 1963 by giving one month's notice.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly the State Government terminated the services of the said personnel with effect from March 31, 1963 by giving one months notice

facts.text: State offered re-employment to those who elected on scales of pay and conditions of State Public Works Department.

anchor.surface_text: but the State also made it clear that such of those who elected to be re- employed on the scales of pay and conditions of service of the State Public Works Department would be so reemployed.

facts.text: 1200 out of 2300 personnel left their services, remaining 1100 agreed to be reemployed.

anchor.surface_text: On the issue of the notice by the State, 1200 out of 2300 personnel who had continued from before in the work-charged establishment left their services and the remaining 1 1 00 agreed to be reemployed

facts.text: Employees were paid amount equal to retrenchment compensation or wages in lieu of notice.

anchor.surface_text: The employees were paid an amount equal to what they would have received by way of retrenchment compensation or by way of wages in lieu of notice.

facts.text: Personnel raised dispute contesting termination, conciliation failed.

anchor.surface_text: Subsequently the personnel of the work-charged establishment raised a dispute contesting the termination of their services by the State. As conciliation failed,

facts.text: Government referred dispute to Industrial Tribunal Orissa by order dated February 13, 1964.

anchor.surface_text: the Government by its order dated February 13, 1964 referred the dispute to the Industrial Tribunal Orissa for adjudication.

facts.text: Industrial Tribunal held termination invalid as not authorized by paragraph 11 of the Code before completion of work except for punishment.

anchor.surface_text: The Industrial Tribunal recorded broadly the following findings ... paragraph 11 of the Code does not authorise the State to terminate the services of an employee before the work is completed. The said paragraph gives only a limited power to terminate the services of an employee by way of a punitive action

facts.text: Industrial Tribunal held work-charged employees entitled to original conditions of service including scales of pay and dearness allowance.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal ultimately held that the action taken by the Management of the Hirakud Dam Project in pursuance of the Notice dated February 9, 1963 was invalid and illegal and that the work-charged employees then working in different divisions of the Project and who had been recruited prior to April 1, 1960 are entitled to have their original conditions of service including scales ,of pay and dearness allowance.

facts.text: State challenged Tribunal award in Orissa High Court in O.J.C. No. 58 of 1965 under Articles 226 and 227.

anchor.surface_text: The State challenged this award before the High Court of Orissa in Writ Petition  O.J.C. No. 58 of1965  under Articles 226 and 227 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Orissa High Court held that under paragraph 11 of the Code, State had power to terminate services even during progress of work on one month's notice.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court agreed with the contention of the State and held that under paragraph 11 of the Code, the State Government had power to terminate the services of an employee even during the progress of the work on giving one months notice or one months pay in lieu of notice.

facts.text: Employees contended before Tribunal that they are entitled to remain in service till termination of work connected with the project.

anchor.surface_text: The main stand taken by the employees before the Industrial Tribunal was that their service conditions being governed by the Code they are entitled to remain in service till the termination of the work connected with the Projects.

facts.text: State contended it has power under paragraph 11 to terminate with one month's notice even before completion of work.

anchor.surface_text: On the other hand, the State of Orissa took up the position that it has power under paragraph 1 1 of the Code they are entitled to remain in service till the termination of notice or one months pay in lieu of notice even before the completion of the work.

facts.text: Notice issued by State dated February 9, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: in pursuance of the Notice dated February 9, 1963

facts.text: Control Board decision on 19th December, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: Whether the Retrenchment of Workmen by the authorities of Hirakud Dam Project effected in pursuance of the decision taken by the Control Board, Hirakud Dam Project on the 19th December, 1962, is valid and legal?

facts.text: Central Public Works Department Code framed in 1929.

anchor.surface_text: It must also be noted that the Code has been framed in 1929 long before the Government of India Act, 1935, came into force.
Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order date April 5, 1968 of the Orissa High Court in O.J.C. No. 58 of 1965.
The State challenged this award before the High Court of Orissa in Writ Petition  O.J.C. No. 58 of1965  under Articles 226 and 227 of the Constitution.
The State challenged this award before the High Court of Orissa in Writ Petition  O.J.C. No. 58 of1965  under Articles 226 and 227 of the Constitution.

holdings.text: The State has power under paragraph 11 of the CPWD Code to terminate the services of work-charged establishment members by giving one month's notice or pay in lieu thereof even before completion of the work.

anchor.surface_text: Paragraph 1 1 of the Code is as follows Members of the temporary and work- charged establishments, who are engaged locally, are on the footing of monthly servants. If they are engaged for a specific work, their engagement lasts only for the period during which the work lasts.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Paragraph 11 treats employees as monthly servants for specific work with automatic termination at work end, but permits earlier dismissal for serious misconduct without notice or otherwise than serious misconduct with notice; natural for employer symmetry with employee resignation right; incongruous to limit to punishment only.

holdings.text: The expression 'dismissed' in paragraph 11 of the CPWD Code is used loosely to include both termination by way of punishment for misconduct and termination simpliciter.

anchor.surface_text: From the above reasoning it is clear that the word dismissed has been used loosely to denote both termination of service for misconduct by way of punishment and also termination of service simpliciter. 65 6 It must also be noted that the Code has been

holdings.reasoning_summary: Contextual reading of para 11 as employment terms; provision for notice when dismissed otherwise than serious misconduct indicates broad meaning; distinguished from technical punitive sense in Art 311, service rules, GOI Acts (post-dating 1929 Code); dictionary meaning ambiguous as any termination; Bool Chand holds dismiss not limited to punishment.

holdings.text: The Industrial Tribunal did not record any finding that the State acted without bona fides in terminating the services; its finding was solely on lack of power under paragraph 11.

anchor.surface_text: We have gone through the reasoning contained in the said paragraph and we do not find any finding recorded by the Tribunal that the State has not acted bona fide, when it passed an order terminating the services of the employees. On the other hand,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct examination of Tribunal's paragraph 18 shows holding based on para 11 interpretation error, not mala fides or arbitrariness beyond legal power.

precedents.citation: Parshotam Lal Dhingra v. Union of India 1

anchor.surface_text: Parshotam Lal Dhingra v. Union of India 1 , this Court observed as follows It follows from the above discussion that both at the date of the companymencement of the 1935 Act and of our Constitution the words dismissed, removed and reduced in rank, as used in the service rules, were all understood as signifying or denoting the three major punishments which could be inflicted on Government ,servants.

precedents.case_name: Parshotam Lal Dhingra v. Union of India
precedents.cited_proposition: the words dismissed, removed and reduced in rank, as used in the service rules, were all understood as signifying or denoting the three major punishments which could be inflicted on Government servants
precedents.cited_holding: both at the date of the commencement of the 1935 Act and of our Constitution the words dismissed, removed and reduced in rank, as used in the service rules, were all understood as signifying or denoting the three major punishments which could be inflicted on Government servants

precedents.citation: Dr. Bool Chand v. The Chancellor, Kurukshetra University 1

anchor.surface_text: In Dr. Bool Chand v. The Chancellor, Kurukshetra Univer- sity 1 , the import of the expression dismissed came up for companysideration before this Court. The appellant in that case, who was Professor and Head of the Department of Political Science in the Punjab University, was appointed on June 18, 1965, as the Vice-Chancellor of the Kurukshetra University.

precedents.case_name: Dr. Bool Chand v. The Chancellor, Kurukshetra University
precedents.cited_proposition: the expression dismiss does not in its etymological sense necessarily involve any such meaning as determination of employment as a penalty; such implication is a matter of recent development since the Government of India Act, 1935
precedents.cited_holding: s. 14 of the General Clauses Act is a general provision ... the expression dismiss ... was intended to be used only in the sense of determination of employment as a measure of punishment

justification_sets.label: Natural Justice - Audi Alteram Partem support
Natural Justice - Audi Alteram Partem support

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Ramamurthy raised the contention that even if there is power of termination simpliciter in the employer under Paragraph 11 , the High Court should not have interfered with the award of the Industrial Tribunal as the Tribunal has recorded a finding that the State has not acted bona fide. In support of this contention-, the learned counsel relied on the reasoning contained in paragraph 18 of the award. We have gone through the reasoning contained in the said paragraph and we do not find any finding recorded by the Tribunal that the State has not acted bona fide, when it passed an order terminating the services of the employees. On the other hand, what the Tribunal has held in the said paragraph is that the termination of the services of the employees is invalid and illegal as it is not warranted by Paragraph 11 of the Code and hence the order of termination is invalid in law and inoperative. There is absolutely no basis for the contention that these findings are to the effect that the action of the State is not bona fide. Thus the findings recorded by the Tribunal are findings on the basis of the interpretation placed by it on Paragraph 11 that the State has no power to terminate simpliciter the services of a work-charged establishment. Therefore, this contention of Mr, Ramamurthy has to be rejected.

outcome.relief_summary: Appellants' final contention rejected; High Court judgment upheld; Tribunal's interpretation of paragraph 11 of the Code set aside implicitly; State's power to terminate services confirmed

anchor.surface_text: Paragraph 1 1 of the Code is as follows Members of the temporary and work- charged establishments, who are engaged locally, are on the footing of monthly servants. If they are engaged for a specific work, their engagement lasts only for the period during which the work lasts.

Mr. Ramamurthy raised the contention that even if there is power of termination simpliciter in the employer under Paragraph 11 , the High Court should not have interfered with the award of the Industrial Tribunal as the Tribunal has recorded a finding that the State has not acted bona fide. In support of this contention-, the learned counsel relied on the reasoning contained in paragraph 18 of the award. We have gone through the reasoning contained in the said paragraph and we do not find any finding recorded by the Tribunal that the State has not acted bona fide, when it passed an order terminating the services of the employees. On the other hand, what the Tribunal has held in the said paragraph is that the termination of the services of the employees is invalid and illegal as it is not warranted by Paragraph 11 of the Code and hence the order of termination is invalid in law and inoperative. There is absolutely no basis for the contention that these findings are to the effect that the action of the State is not bona fide. Thus the findings recorded by the Tribunal are findings on the basis of the interpretation placed by it on Paragraph 11 that the State has no power to terminate simpliciter the services of a work-charged establishment. Therefore, this contention of Mr, Ramamurthy has to be rejected.
